user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimerGetInfo(osal_id_t timer_id, OS_timer_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timecb_internal_record_t *  timecb;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timecb_table, token);
        timecb   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timecb_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, timecb->timebase_token);

        strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1);
        timer_prop->creator       = record->creator;
        timer_prop->interval_time = (uint32)timecb->interval_time;
        timer_prop->accuracy      = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimerGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    uint32    start_time;
    uint32    interval_time;
    uint32    accuracy;
} OS_timer_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char              timer_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    uint32            flags;
    OS_object_token_t timebase_token;
    osal_id_t         prev_cb;
    osal_id_t         next_cb;
    uint32            backlog_resets;
    int32             wait_time;
    int32             interval_time;
    OS_ArgCallback_t  callback_ptr;
    void *            callback_arg;
} OS_timecb_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_timecb_table
...
OS_timecb_internal_record_t OS_timecb_table[OS_MAX_TIMERS]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The listed fragments are pointer declarations/uses and table-access macros that should be investigated for Rule 8.13 (they are used only for reading in this function and could be const-qualified pointers or the tables could be exposed as const). Other code fragments do not need investigation for this rule because they either legitimately require mutable pointers or are not pointer declarations: - The parameter OS_timer_prop_t *timer_prop is an output buffer written to (memset/strncpy/assignments), so it must remain non-const. - The token variable is passed by address to OS_ObjectIdGetById/OS_ObjectIdRelease and is modified by those APIs, so it must be mutable. - return_code, objtype and other scalar locals are non-pointer values and not relevant to Rule 8.13. - The calls to OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl, OS_TaskGetId_Impl and the OS_CHECK_POINTER macro are API usages that require non-const arguments as shown; they are not pointer declarations that could/should be const-qualified here. - The strncpy and subsequent assignments write into timer_prop (mutable destination), so those pointer/data accesses are intentionally non-const. Thus the investigation should focus on the listed pointer declarations, their assignments via the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro, the global table definitions, and the pointer fields in the timecb struct.
